overview.short: Rothia species are Gram-positive cocci that are part of the normal oral and upper respiratory tract flora.
overview.clinical_context: Typically opportunistic pathogens, most often associated with oral infections, endocarditis, and infections in immunocompromised hosts.

field_notes.Colony Morphology: Colonies may appear dry, chalky, or crumbly, particularly with prolonged incubation.
field_notes.Catalase: Catalase positivity helps separate Rothia from many Streptococcus species.
field_notes.Shape: Although pleomorphic arrangements may be described microscopically, Rothia is categorised as cocci in this schema.

key_differentiators.notes: Catalase positivity helps differentiate Rothia from catalase-negative Gram-positive cocci.
Dry, crumbly colonies are more typical of Rothia than Staphylococcus.

common_confusions.reason: Shared catalase positivity and Gram-positive cocci morphology.
Chalky colonies and oral flora association may cause confusion.
Overlap in oral habitat and colony texture in older cultures.

when_to_question_identification: Strong beta haemolysis suggests an alternative genus.
Motility or spore formation argues against Rothia.
Oxidase positivity is inconsistent with Rothia.

recommended_next_tests.reason: Most reliable routine method for identifying Rothia to species level.
Useful for confirmation in rare or atypical clinical isolates.
